svg.text: Pre-Data Science Era: Report Structure vs Legacy Methods
Modern Report Layout with Traditional Development Approaches (1990s-2013)

g.text: Customer acquisition cost decreased by 18% while maintaining
quality leads, resulting in improved ROI across all channels.
Increase investment in digital marketing channels by 25%
Expand customer success team to maintain NPS above 70
Implement automated reporting for real-time insights
Focus on retention strategies for high-value segments
A. Detailed methodology | B. Raw data | C. Statistical tests | D. References
â€¢ SAS: Enterprise Guide, BASE, STAT procedures
â€¢ SPSS: Statistics, syntax files, point-and-click interface
â€¢ S-PLUS: Statistical modeling (predecessor to R)
â€¢ Steep learning curve, procedural syntax
â€¢ Excel: VBA macros, pivot tables, manual charts
â€¢ Crystal Reports: Formatted reports from databases
â€¢ MS Access: Database forms, queries, basic reports
â€¢ Workflow: Manual data entry â†’ Excel â†’ PowerPoint
â€¢ Limited automation, prone to human error
â€¢ Oracle: Expensive enterprise database with Forms
â€¢ SQL Server: Microsoft database with SSRS reporting
â€¢ IBM DB2: Mainframe and enterprise systems
â€¢ ETL: Manual processes, stored procedures
â€¢ Batch processing, overnight jobs common
SELECT * FROM sales WHERE date > sysdate-30;
â€¢ PDF: Static reports printed and distributed physically
â€¢ PowerPoint: Static charts, manual updates required
â€¢ Word Documents: Text-heavy reports with tables
â€¢ Email: Attachments sent to distribution lists
â€¢ Fax: Still common for official documents!
â€¢ Physical filing cabinets for report archives
4. Print to PDF, email to stakeholders
